revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=December 2008}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = 150px | | name = Shecky Greene | caption = | birthname = Fred Sheldon Greenfield | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1926|04|8}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Comedian | spouse = Nalani Kele (1972â€“1982; divorced)
Marie Musso (1985â€“present)}} '''Shecky Greene''' (born '''Fred Sheldon Greenfield'''; April 8, 1926)[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0008_0_07858.html Profile], JewishVirtualLibrary.org; accessed April 7, 2016. is an American comedian. He is known for his nightclub performances in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], where he became a headliner in the 1950s.{{cite web|title=Legend Shecky Greene Returns to Las Vegas|url=http://www.lasvegasnow.com/news/legend-shecky-greene-returns-to-las-vegas/78122248 |publisher=Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc.|accessdate=2017-03-27}} He has appeared in several films, including ''[[Tony Rome]]'', ''[[History of the World, Part I]]'' and ''[[Splash (film)|Splash]]'', and has guest starred on such television shows as ''[[Mad About You]]'', ''[[Laverne & Shirley]]'', ''[[Love, American Style]]'', and ''[[Combat!]]'' ==Biography== Greene was born in 1926, and grew up on the [[North Side, Chicago|North Side of Chicago]]{{cite web|url=http://smdp.com/ladies-and-gentlemen-shecky-greene/154325|title=Ladies and gentlemen, Shecky Greene!|website=smdp.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jodavidsmeyer.com/combat/personnel/bio_greene.html|title=Shecky Greene biography|website=www.jodavidsmeyer.com}} and servedhttps://books.google.com/books?id=kuV8BM5Hul4C&pg=PT115&lpg=PT115&dq=Shecky "Comedian Shecky Greene sailed aboard the aircraft carrier Bon Homme Richard." in the [[United States Navy]] during [[World War II]]. Greene had planned to become a gym teacher, but had been performing comedy at various venues in the upper Midwest, and started his comedy career at the Prevue Lounge in New Orleans, where he worked for six years.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/jan/09/magazine/tm-shecky02|title=Leaving Las Vegas|date=January 9, 2005|work=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=November 28, 2015}} From there he went on to showrooms in [[Miami]], Chicago, and [[Reno]]/[[Lake Tahoe]] before an agent persuaded him to move to Las Vegas and open in 1954 for [[Dorothy Shay]], "the [[Park Avenue (Manhattan)|Park Avenue]] Hillbillie," at the Last Frontier. His act was held over for 18 weeks, a first for that venue.{{cite web|title=Shecky Greene has become the man he wants to be|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/1996/dec/26/shecky-greene----probably-the-most-gifted-comedian/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=1996-12-26|accessdate=2017-03-27}}
"He invented a hysterical, free-form approach to comedy that the confines of a five minute television spot could not handle."{{cite web|url=http://blog.wfmu.org/freeform/2011/06/the-legend-of-shecky-greene.html|title=Outrageous and Courageous: The Myth and Legend of Shecky Greene by Kliph Nesteroff - WFMU's Beware of the Blog|website=blog.wfmu.org}}{{cite web|url=http://classicshowbiz.blogspot.com/2011/06/interview-with-shecky-greene-part-one.html|title=Classic Television Showbiz: An Interview with Shecky Greene - Part One|first=Kliph|last=Nesteroff|date=20 June 2011|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://classicshowbiz.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-shecky-greene-part-two.html|title=Classic Television Showbiz: An Interview with Shecky Greene - Part Two|first=Kliph|last=Nesteroff|date=23 June 2011|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5UlkCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT148&lpg=PT148&dq=Shecky|title=The Comedians: Drunks, Thieves, Scoundrels, and the History of American Comedy|first=Kliph|last=Nesteroff|date=3 November 2015|publisher=Grove/Atlantic, Inc.|via=Google Books}}
Offstage, his main passion was horse racing. A thoroughbred horse named Shecky Greene{{cite web|url=http://www.allbreedpedigree.com/shecky+greene|title=Shecky Greene Thoroughbred|first=Miles|last=Michelson|website=www.allbreedpedigree.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.poundfeinstein.com/2013/10/11/no-one-remembers-shecky-greene/|title=Pound, Feinstein & Associates Â» No one remembers Shecky Greene|website=www.poundfeinstein.com}} (January 30, 1970 - March 9, 1984) was the 1973 Eclipse Champion Sprinter and the frontrunner for nearly seven furlongs in the 1973 [[Kentucky Derby]] until [[Secretariat (horse)|Secretariat]] ran off with the race. Arlington Park in [[Illinois]] still runs a Shecky Greene Handicap. When the [[Bally's Las Vegas|MGM Grand Hotel]] opened in 1975, starring [[Dean Martin]], the second headline act was Shecky Greene, whose salary at one point climbed to $150,000 a week ($125,000 went to "my bookmaker," Greene cracks).{{cite web|title=Ladies and Gentlemen, Shecky Greene!|url=http://smdp.com/ladies-and-gentlemen-shecky-greene/154325|work=Santa Monica Daily Press|date=2016-03-25|accessdate=2017-03-27}} Greene played [[Carnegie Hall]] and appeared on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' (which he hated: "They'd rush you on and off"). He played Pvt. Braddock for a year on ''[[Combat!]]'' and guested on ''[[The Joey Bishop Show (sitcom)|The Joey Bishop Show]]'', ''[[The Love Boat]]'', Lou Carnesco in two episodes of ''[[The Fall Guy]]'' and a fourth-season 1985 episode of ''[[The A-Team]]'' entitled "Members Only". Greene was widely respected by his peers, including [[Johnny Carson]], who was a longtime fan. Greene made 40 appearances on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.johnnycarson.com/carson/search.do?name=shecky+green&singleDateMonth=Month&singleDateDay=Day&singleDateYear=Year&dateRangeBeginMonth=Month&dateRangeBeginDay=Day&dateRangeBeginYear=Year&dateRangeEndMonth=Month&dateRangeEndDay=Day&dateRangeEndYear=Year&x=32&y=14|title=Tonight Show Samplers|accessdate=May 6, 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=https://www.johnnycarson.com/search?q=Shecky+Greene|title=Shecky Greene|website=JohnnyCarson.com}} on which he also served as a guest host. He appeared on ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]'', serving as a guest host on that show as well. He notes that he gave [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and [[Luciano Pavarotti]] their first national television exposure. He also appeared on the ''[[Match Game]]'' in the 1970s.{{Cite web |url=https://instagram.com/p/BRPcNbBD93o/|title=Instagram post by Things That Made Me LOL ðŸ˜‚ â€¢ Mar 5, 2017 at 3:25am UTC |publisher=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2017-03-05}} He was recruited for [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] shows but turned them down. One of his standard jokes in [[Las Vegas]] and on television went like this: "Johnny was a good boy, never smoked, never drank, never dated. On his graduation day from college, his parents asked what he wanted. Johnny replied, 'A drunken broad that smokes.'" Greene claims [[Jay Leno]] once told him that his all-time favorite joke is one Greene recounted about [[Frank Sinatra]] (with whom Greene had a contentious relationship) 'saving his life'. Offended by a remark made by Greene, Sinatra sent five men to assault him;{{cite web|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/books/he-did-it-his-way-the-nice-and-nasty-of-sinatra-34198094.html|title=He did it his way: The nice and nasty of Sinatra|publisher=|via=www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.lasvegasnow.com/news/legend-shecky-greene-returns-to-las-vegas/78122248|title=Legend Shecky Greene Returns to Las Vegas|date=27 August 2010|publisher=}} after some time, he heard Sinatra say, "OK. He's had enough."{{cite web|title=Legend Shecky Greene Returns to Las 0Vegas|url=http://www.lasvegasnow.com/news/legend-shecky-greene-returns-to-las-vegas/78122248|publisher=Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc.|accessdate=2017-03-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/shecky-greene-doesn-pull-punch-lines-article-1.678396|title=SHECKY GREENE DOESN'T PULL ANY PUNCH LINES - NY Daily News|first=PHIL|last=ROURA|publisher=}} Greene suffered from panic attacks{{cite web|url=https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/the-hilarity-of-influence-an-interview-with-kliph-nesteroff/|title=The Hilarity of Influence: An Interview with Kliph Nesteroff - Los Angeles Review of Books|publisher=}} and stage fright and didn't perform for six years at one point.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-10-16/entertainment/ca-51012_1_shecky-greene|title=COMEDY : It's Not Easy Being Greene : Did you hear the one about the comic whose life became a nightmare of gambling, alcohol, panic attacks and prescription drugs? Shecky Greene can tell it.|first=Lawrence|last=Christon|date=16 October 1994|publisher=|via=LA Times}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p6c-K6fneFY YouTube]; accessed April 7, 2016. After an absence of many years, Greene returned to perform in Las Vegas in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.lvrj.com/news/45079872.html|title=Shecky Greene's Return to Las Vegas Stirs Up Memories of Sinatra, Caesars|author=Smith, John L.|date=May 15, 2009|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=December 26, 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/entertainment-columns/kats/shecky-greene-knows-slapstick-but-fall-at-italian-club-is-the-real-thing/|title=Shecky Greene knows slapstick, but fall at Italian club is the real thing|date=23 March 2017|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2015/jul/24/fountains-incident-recalls-night-caesars-palace-st/|title=Fountains incident recalls night at Caesars Palace starring Shecky Greene|date=24 July 2015|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2014/05/07/gilbert-gottfried-is-offended-youre-offended/|title=Gilbert Gottfried Is Offended Youâ€™re Offended|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/frank-sinatra-and-the-scandalous-but-scholarly-biography|title=Frank Sinatra and the Scandalous but Scholarly Biography|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elvis-history-blog.com/elvis-las-vegas-56.html|title=Elvis Presley's at the Frontier Hotel in Las Vegas 1956|publisher=}} ==Personal life== He has been married, since 1985, to Marie Musso, daughter of [[Vido Musso]], a prominent Las Vegas musician who played [[saxophone]] with [[Benny Goodman]]. ==Filmography== *''[[Tony Rome]]'' (1967) â€“ Catleg *''[[The Love Machine (film)|The Love Machine]]'' (1971) â€“ Christie Lane *''[[Won Ton Ton, the Dog Who Saved Hollywood]]'' (1976) â€“ Tourist *''[[History of the World, Part I]]'' (1981) â€“ Marcus Vindictus *''[[Splash (film)|Splash]]'' (1984) â€“ Mr. Buyrite *''[[Lovelines (film)|Lovelines]]'' (1984) â€“ Master of Ceremonies *''[[The Last Producer]]'' (2000) â€“ Poker Player ==References== Myth and Legend of Shecky Greene by Kliph Nesteroff - WFMU] *[http://classicshowbiz.blogspot.com/2011/06/interview-with-shecky-greene-part-one.html An interview with Shecky Greene, June 2011, Part One] *[http://classicshowbiz.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-shecky-greene-part-two.html An interview with Shecky Greene, June 2011, Part Two] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Greene, Shecky}}
